raw_text:
Nintendo DS aims to touch gamers
 
 The mobile gaming industry is set to explode in 2005 with a number of high-profile devices offering a range of gaming and other features such as movie and music playback. Market leader Nintendo, however, is releasing a handheld console that it says will revolutionise the way games are played.
 
 The first striking thing about the DS is how retro it looks. Far from looking like a mould-breaking handheld, it looks more like Nintendo dug out a mould from a 1980s handheld prototype. The lightweight clam shell device opens up to reveal two screens, and when switched on it instantly reveals its pedigree. Both screens are crisp and clear while the bottom of the two is touch sensitive. Nintendo has given developers free rein to utilise the dual screens and ability to control the action by simply touching the screen.
 
 The Japanese gaming giant hopes the DS will maintain the firm's pre-eminence in an increasingly-competitive mobile gaming market.
 
 Nintendo first launched its GameBoy console in 1989 and has dominated the market ever since. But its lead can no longer be taken for granted. Sony will enter the market later this year with its PlayStation Portable, while start-up companies Gizmondo and Tapwave Zodiac are also offering hybrid devices. "We believe the DS will appeal to all ages, both genders and gamers of any skill," said David Yarnton, Nintendo Europe's general manager said at the recent press launch for the handheld. With its two screens, wireless connectivity and backwards compatibility with the GameBoy Advance, the DS certainly has a number of unique selling points. It went on sale in the US in mid-November priced $150 and Nintendo says sales have exceeded expectations, without giving detailed figures. Japan and Europe will have to wait until the first quarter of 2005 to get the device. With more than two million pre-orders for the device in Japan, Nintendo is confident it will keep its number one spot. But will the device prove to be as revolutionary as claimed? The game ships with a demo of Metroid Hunters - a 3D action title which can be played alone or with a group of friends using the machine's wireless capabilities. It certainly looks impressive on the small machine and plays smoothly even with a group of people.
 
 The game can be controlled by using the supplied stylus to aim. The top screen is used to navigate the action while the bottom screen offers a top-down map and the ability to switch weapons. It is certainly a unique control method and while it makes aiming more controlled it can be a little disorientating. Super Mario 64 DS is a faithful re-creation of the Nintendo 64 classic with a host of new mini-games and new levels. The game looks stunning on the portable machine and the sound too is impressive for such a small machine. One thing is for certain. Hardened gamers will have to learn to adapt to a new way of playing while it could prove to be an accessible way in to gaming for novices, Ultimately the success or failure of the device lies in the hands of developers. If they manage to create titles which use the Nintendo DS's key features then a whole new market of gamers could open up. The fear is that the touch screen and voice recognition are treated as little more than gimmicks.
llama3.2:1b: Nintendo DS aims to provide gaming on the go with its retro-style handheld console, featuring dual screens and wireless connectivity. Released in 2004, it will compete with Sony's PlayStation Portable and other hybrid devices. With over two million pre-orders in Japan, Nintendo is confident sales will exceed expectations. The device offers backwards compatibility with GameBoy Advance, a demo of the action game Metroid Hunters, and supports multiplayer controls via stylus.
llama3.2:3b: Nintendo DS aims to revolutionize handheld gaming with its dual screens, touchscreen control, and wireless connectivity, targeting all ages and skill levels. The device's unique design and features, such as backwards compatibility and demo games like Metroid Hunters and Super Mario 64 DS, have exceeded sales expectations in the US, but its success depends on developers creating titles that effectively utilize these features.
gemma2:2b: The Nintendo DS, aiming for revolutionizing gaming with its dual screens, lightweight design, and backwards compatibility, is poised to compete in the booming mobile gaming market.  Nintendo emphasizes the device's accessibility and unique features like wireless connectivity and stylus control. The success of the DS will hinge on developers creating innovative titles that utilize its capabilities.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS, aims to revolutionize mobile gaming by offering a dual-screen device with touch sensitivity. It includes two screens, one for action and another for navigation, allowing developers to control the game using just touches on the screen. While the game ships with a demo of Metroid Hunters - a 3D action title that can be played alone or with friends - it is designed as a comprehensive gaming experience rather than a gimmick.

The DS also features wireless connectivity and backwards compatibility with previous Nintendo console games, making it an ideal solution for gamers who prefer traditional methods but don't have access to the latest hardware. It is projected to go on sale in Japan by mid-2005, priced at $150. Nintendo claims its sales so far exceed expectations without giving detailed figures.

Overall, the DS promises a more immersive gaming experience and could potentially become a major player in the mobile gaming market. However, developers will need to adapt their titles to work with this new technology.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Nintendo DS aims to appeal to all ages, genders, and skill levels in the mobile gaming market by offering unique dual-screen, wireless connectivity, backwards compatibility features along with a demo of Metroid Hunters and Super Mario 64 DS. The handheld console has pre-orders exceeding two million in Japan and sales exceeded expectations, but its success remains uncertain as developers create titles utilizing Nintendo DS's key features.
qwen2.5:3b: Nintendo DS aims to revolutionize handheld gaming with its retro design featuring two screens, touch sensitivity, and innovative control methods. It promises unique selling points including wireless connectivity, backwards compatibility, and an appealing range of games such as Metroid Hunters and Super Mario 64 DS. With high-profile competitors entering the market, Nintendo hopes this device will appeal to all ages, genders, and skill levels, maintaining its dominance in mobile gaming. Successful game development leveraging the DS's features is crucial for its success.
opencoder:1.5b:
Nintendo DS aims to touch gamers

The mobile gaming industry is set to explode in 2005 with high-profile devices offering a range of gaming and other features like movie and music playback. Market leader Nintendo, however, has released a handheld console that promises an evolution in how games are played. The first striking feature about the DS is its retro look, making it look more like Mario dug out a mould from a handheld prototype. The lightweight device features two screens, with one screen prominently visible to the player and the other for navigation or to display information. It has touch-sensitive areas which allow players to interact with the game easily.

Nintendo has positioned itself as a major player in the mobile gaming market, but it remains to be seen how successful its hybrid devices are going to be based on pre-orders in Japan. The device will need to wait until the first quarter of 2005 before it can be launched internationally, and with more than two million pre-orders for the handheld in Japan, Nintendo is confident it'll keep its number one spot.

Despite these challenges, the handheld promises new possibilities in gaming experience. With enhanced controls, including touch screen for aiming, and a host of additional mini-games, gamers will find the device to be unique and powerful in their gaming endeavors.
smollm:1.7b:
The Nintendo DS aims to touch gamers by offering a unique gaming experience on a small, portable device. The device has two screens, one for each player, which allows for a more immersive gaming experience compared to other handheld consoles. The DS also features wireless connectivity and backwards compatibility with the GameBoy Advance, making it easy to play games with friends or family members.
The DS's unique control method, where players use the stylus to aim, is innovative and provides a new way of playing games on small screens. The top screen is used to navigate the action while the bottom screen offers a top-down map and the ability to switch weapons. The game can be controlled by using the supplied stylus to aim, which makes it easy for players to focus on the gameplay.
The DS's sound system is also impressive, with clear and immersive audio that makes the gaming experience more engaging. The game sounds are designed to work well in small rooms or outdoors, making it a great option for casual gamers who want to play games in different environments.
Overall, the Nintendo DS aims to touch gamers by offering a unique gaming experience on a small, portable device with innovative control methods and impressive sound quality.

It highlights how the device offers two screens, allowing easy use and development, with a retro aesthetic appealing to retro gaming fans. Despite initial praise from sales figures, resist the screen design as a gimmick, while hard gamers can adapt with new controls.
tinyllama:1.1b: NinteendS aimed to revolutionize mobile gaming with its "Dual Screen" handheld console, featuring a touch-sensitive bottom screen and dual screens for a total of two games at once. The device boasts a game called "Metroid Hunter," a 3D action title that can be played alone or with friends using the machine's wireless capabilities, along with stylus to navigate. The top screen is used to aim, while the bottom screen offers a top-down map and controls for switching weapons. However, despite impressive graphics and sounds, some developers may struggle to make use of the DS's unique control method, particularly in regards to adapting to new gameplay mechanics.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Nintendo has developed an innovative handheld console with unique features such as two screens, multitouch capabilities, wireless connectivity, a built-in rechargeable battery, and a plethora of exclusive games. It will be available in the US on November 15th, priced at $150, and will be launched across Europe in early 2005. The console was officially unveiled by Nintendo Europe's general manager, David Yarnton at a press event in London.
phi:2.7b: Nintendo's GameBoy handheld was first released in 198S, but its successor, the Nintendo DS, aims to revolutionize gaming by offering two screens, wireless connectivity, touch controls, and backwards compatibility with the GameBoy Advance. Despite competition from other mobile gaming devices, Nintendo believes it will appeal to all ages, genders, and skill levels. The device includes a demo of Metroid Hunters, which can be played alone or with friends using the machine's wireless capabilities, making for a unique control method that requires players to use a stylus to aim. Super Mario 64 DS is a faithful re-creation of the Nintendo 64 classic, offering new mini-games and levels. While it looks impressive on the small device and has stunning visuals, some may find the touch screen and voice recognition gimmicks. Ultimately, the success of the device depends on developers creating titles that utilize its key features to attract a whole new market of gamers.
orca-mini:3b: The Nintendo DS aims to revolutionize handheld gaming by offering unique features such as two screens, wireless connectivity, and backwards compatibility with GameBoy Advance games. Market leader Nintendo hopes the device will maintain its pre-eminence in an increasingly competitive mobile gaming market dominated by Sony's PlayStation Portable and new start-up companies Gizmondo and Tapwave Zodiac. The firsthand look at Metroid Hunters demonstrates that the device can play smoothly with a group of friends using the machine's wireless capabilities. However, whether the Nintendo DS will prove to be as revolutionary as claimed remains to be seen, especially since some developers have been criticized for relying too heavily on touch screen and voice recognition features as gimmicks.
hermes3:3b: Nintendo DS aims to revolutionize mobile gaming with dual screens, touch sensitivity, wireless connectivity, and backward compatibility for GameBoy Advance.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Nintendo DS, launching in 2005, aimed to revolutionize handheld gaming with dual screens, touch sensitivity, and wireless connectivity. Positioning itself as a device for all ages and gamers, Nintendo hoped to maintain its dominance in the competitive mobile gaming market. The company's success relied on developers creating games that utilized the unique features of the device. While some criticized it as having gimmicky touches, early sales exceeded expectations, with more than two million pre-orders in Japan. The DS proved successful due to its impressive display and sound quality, offering a new way to play for both hardcore gamers and novices into gaming.

Early games like Metroid Hunters and Super Mario 64 DS showcase its innovative controls, but its success depends on developers fully utilizing its features rather than treating them as gimmicks.

As we all know, there are several kinds of braces available – traditional metal braces, clear plastic aligners, and even Invisalign trays. Each type has its own advantages and disadvantages when it comes to treatment time, cost, comfort, and overall appearance.
Traditional metal braces are probably the most well-known kind of braces. They have been around for decades and have become a popular choice for many people because they're effective at correcting misaligned or crooked teeth. Metal braces can be quite bulky and unsightly, but they also provide excellent results. Treatment time usually ranges from 12 to 36 months, depending on the severity of your case.
Clear plastic aligners are another option for those who want a more discreet approach to orthodontic treatment. These are similar to metal braces in many ways, except that they're much less noticeable. They consist of clear plastic trays that gradually shift your teeth into the desired position. Treatment time is often shorter than with traditional braces (usually 12-18 months), but some people may need more or fewer aligners depending on their individual needs.
Invisalign is a newer type of orthodontic treatment that uses clear, plastic aligners to guide your teeth into the right position. Unlike metal braces, which you'll have to wear all the time, Invisalign trays are worn only during the day (and overnight) while you sleep. This makes for a much more comfortable experience and means you can avoid some of the discomfort associated with wearing traditional braces. Treatment time is also usually shorter than with traditional braces (usually 12-24 months), but again, it may vary depending on your individual needs.
Of course, there are many other types of braces available as well, such PPOs and indemnity plans that require little to no out-of-pocket expenses for participants.
In conclusion, the benefits of employer-sponsored health insurance plans include cost savings for both the company and its employees. These plans often provide coverage for a wide range of medical services, from routine check-ups to specialized treatments. By offering such comprehensive benefits, employers can attract and retain top talent, boost employee morale, and lower absenteeism rates.
However, it's important for companies to carefully evaluate their healthcare options and consider the potential costs associated with providing these benefits. With the right approach, however, employer-sponsored health insurance plans can provide significant advantages for both employees and employers alike.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Nintendo's new handheld console, the Nintendo DS, aims to revolutionize mobile gaming with its unique dual-screen design and innovative control methods. Launched in mid-November 2004 for $150 in the US, it has surpassed expectations in sales, with over two million pre-orders in Japan. The device, which maintains a retro appearance reminiscent of early Nintendo handhelds, features two screens that can be manipulated by touch controls or a stylus. This setup allows for diverse gameplay experiences, including 3D action titles like Metroid Hunters and faithful re-creations of classic games such as Super Mario 64 DS. Nintendo expects the DS to appeal to all age groups and skill levels, potentially challenging competitors like Sony's PlayStation Portable and other hybrid devices. The device's success hinges on developers' ability to create engaging titles that effectively utilize its distinctive features, avoiding mere gimmickry.
